title: 114_s1990
content: The Act may be cited as the "Federal Computer Security Act" and includes definitions for key terms. The "Federal Computer Security Act" defines key terms such as agency, covered agency, logical access control, and multi-factor logical access controls. The "Federal Computer Security Act" defines multi-factor logical access controls as a set of at least 2 of the following: user-known information, access device, or unique biometric characteristic. SEC. 3. Inspector General report on federal computer systems. Inspector Generals of covered agencies must submit a report to the Comptroller General and relevant committees within 240 days of the Act's enactment. The report should include information on the Federal computer systems and logical access standards used by the agencies. The covered agency must provide a description of the logical access standards used to access Federal computer systems containing classified or personally identifiable information, including a list and description of access controls and whether multi-factor controls are used. The covered agency must describe the use of multi-factor logical access controls for accessing Federal computer systems containing classified or personally identifiable information. If such controls are not used, reasons for their absence must be provided. Additionally, data security management practices, including policies and procedures, must be outlined. The covered agency must describe data security management practices, including conducting inventories of software and licenses, and using software security controls for monitoring threats like data loss prevention. The covered agency must describe using data loss prevention and digital rights management software to monitor and detect threats, and provide a description of how the software is being utilized. If the agency is not using such software, reasons for not doing so must be explained. The covered agency must describe the policies and procedures for ensuring entities, including contractors, implement data security management practices. The report required may be based on an audit, evaluation, or report related to agency programs or practices. Based on an audit, evaluation, or report related to agency programs, a report submitted under this section must be in unclassified form but may include a classified annex. It must be made available to any Member of Congress upon request. The Comptroller General of the United States will submit a report to Congress within 1 year of this Act's enactment, analyzing impediments to agency use of security software and devices. The report may include a classified annex but must be in unclassified form.
